channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report E-2024040300
item.description:
Report E-2024040300

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-15T15:12:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-11
  • City: FOREST HILL
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LFW experienced a UN3098 NIL 8 release from a 2.5-gallon poly jerrican. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.5 cups of product released to a 1.5’ x 3” area of the trailer floor. The remaining material in the jug released into the poly bag/absorbents the pail was contained too prior to the crew’s arrival. The empty damaged jug, poly bag, absorbent and sodium bicarb were placed into a 55-gallon vented poly drum. The trailer floor was cleaned and neutralized with sodium bicarb. The impacted oil dri, neutralizer, impacted pallet wood, and poly 5-gallon pail which held the absorbents were placed into a second 55-gallon vented poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024040258
item.description:
Report E-2024040258

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-15T15:12:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-10
  • City: NEWARK
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XNJ experienced a UN1210 PS-PX93 Proshine Process Ext. release from a 55-gallon metal drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 55-gallons of product released to a 36’ x 24’ area of the concrete dock floor due to a forklift puncture. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon metal overpack. Absorbents were then worked into the impacted area. The impacted absorbents were collected into (4) 55-gallon metal drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

The damaged case of tubes, impacted "Oil Dri", and spent PPE were containerized into a 55-gallon metal drum.

item.title: Report X-2024040710
item.description:
Report X-2024040710

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-15T15:12:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-04
  • City: ROANOKE
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: NORFOLK SOUTHERN CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Mechanical employee conducting an outbound inspection noticed the strong smell of sulfur in the area of SHPX 209817. He left the area and reported it. NS Haz Mat and contractor responded checked the car and found high S02 reading around the manway area. We could also hear a hissing from the manway. Tightening manway bolts did not stop leak. Manway was opened and found to have two (2) gaskets in place, one flat in the manway cover and one mounted on the manway nozzle. Both gaskets were removed and replaced with new one. Manway was secured and tested with meter. No detect. Car was release for transportation.

item.title: Report E-2024040256
item.description:
Report E-2024040256

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-15T15:12:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-03
  • City: WILMINGTON
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On April 3, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN3098 was damaged prior to arrival and released approximately 55-gallons of product to the trailer interior and further migrated to the asphalt. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews collected the damaged 55-gallon drum and placed it in a 95-gallon over-pack drum for disposal. TLE deployed soda ash to the impacted asphalt and trailer floor to neutralize the release. Crews utilized hand tools to collect all impacted soda ash from the asphalt and the trailer floor. All hydrogen peroxide and peroxyacetic acid impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 95-gallon drum and thirteen (13) 35-gallon drums and added to RLC waste stream for disposal.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: It was reported 1 gallon of UN 3265 "Pantastic" released from 4-1-gallon plastic jugs impacting the trailer floor due to improper loading by the shipper. Due to the corrosive nature ERTS determined a contractor's assistance would be required. Hepaco arrived on site and found the terminal had placed soda ash on the spill. They pH tested the area and cleaned the impacted area with absorbents. One (1) 55-gallon poly drum with the damaged bottles and spent absorbent were left on site.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On April 3, 2024, one (1) 330-gallon tote of sodium hydroxide was damaged in transit due to a load shift and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from MidSouth Environmental Services (MSES) to remediate the impacted site. MSES personnel utilized a degreasing agent with absorbent wipes to collect any product on the trailer floor. All sodium hydroxide-impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and MSES personnel took possession of the waste.

  • Description: On April 3, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN2874 was damaged due to a shipping error and released approximately one-eighth (1/8) gallon of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Works, Inc. (EWI) to remediate the impacted site. EWI personnel deployed granular absorbents to the UN2874-impacted dock floor and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum. The damaged 55-gallon drum was then placed into one (1) additional 85-gallon drum. Both drums were staged onsite for future disposal.

  • Description: On April 3, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of phosphoric acid was punctured by a forklift and released approximately fifteen (15) gallons of product to the dock floor and pallet. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from ES+ to remediate the impacted site. E3+ personnel deployed absorbents to the release and worked them in with hand tools. The pallet was disassembled and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum. The damaged drum of phosphoric acid was overpacked in one (1) 85-gallon drum. All spent absorbents and impacted materials were containerized in one (1) additional 55-gallon drum. The three (3) waste drums were staged onsite for disposal.

Crews transferred the remaining contents of the damaged tote into two (2) separate 275-gallon totes and label as "DO NOT DELIVER." All waste was collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums and staged onsite with the damaged tote for disposal.

  • Description: On April 2, 2024, nine (9) 1-quart containers of paint were crushed in transit and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of paint to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. ed 1-quart containers of paint (UN1263) and containerized them in one (1) 55-gallon drum as waste. HCE personnel utilized absorbent wipes to collect all released paint (UN1263) from the impacted surfaces of the trailer. All paint (UN1263) impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum and one (1) 5-gallon poly container that were staged on-site in RLC's consolidated waste area.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Hazmat was found in Unload B by the unload manager. Package was brought back to QA hazmat cage for inspection. During the inspection it was found. One glass jug had its closure component broken off. This was the cause of the leakage. Taking a closer look the bottle neck had a small glass piece missing from the bottle, the glass piece looked as though it had broken off. This allowed the cap to lose and come off in transit. DescribePack: One glass jug had its closure component broken off. This was the cause of the leakage. Taking a closer look the bottle neck had a small glass piece missing from the bottle, the glass piece looked as though it had broken off. This allowed the cap to lose and come off in transit. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: No damage was done to other packages. The broken jug had its cap tightened back to the bottle and placed into a 20-gallon salvage drum to prevent vaper and further leakage.

item.title: Report X-2024040266
item.description:
Report X-2024040266

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-15T15:12:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-26
  • City: HUMBOLDT
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Packaged Handlers were unloading a van that had the Hazmat. The Hazmat was toppled over when found and was leaking some of the chloride inside (solid). Package Handlers contacted an Ops Manager and informed QA/Coordinator of the incident. We removed the packaged from the vehicle and put it in a bucket to keep spilling anymore of the contents inside the station. It was taken to the Hazmat cage where upon further inspection found that the Hazmat material was inside of a plastic cylinder (outer container is a cardboard box). While transferring the leaking Hazmat, it was found that the bottom of the cylinder had cracked and was leaking a massive amount of the chlorine. The box itself was already filled halfway with the leaking contents. Admins wore protective gloves and used the ventilation shaft to not inhale the "fumes" of the chloride. The Hazmat was placed in a Hazmat container and DPR/ISF were filled out. DescribePack: The packaged appeared to have been repacked as it has a new label and was missing the shipping documents and had lots of tape wrapped around the closures. Looking at the photos from previous stations before it's arrival to the current one, it was in a much nicer box with better taping/packaging. The bucket likely could have been dropped at some point during it's transport casuing the bottom portion to be cracked, or likely from moving around inside the box as it did not have any filling inside to prevent the contents from moving around. The driver also could have secured the package to stop it from sliding around on the floor, perhaps had it on one of the shelves. DurationRel: 4 and MitigateEffect: Hazmat was removed immediately from the van and into a bucket in order to take it to the hazmat cage.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 25, 2024, eight (8) 50-pound bags of potassium nitrate were damaged by unsecured freight and released approximately one-hundred pounds of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE personnel overpacked the damaged bags in one (1) 55-gallon drum. The crew then utilized hand tools and a vacuum unit to further remediate the site. All potassium nitrate-impacted materials were containerized in one (1) additional 55-gallon drum. Both waste drums were staged onsite for future disposal.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-15T15:12:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-21
  • City: AVINGER
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CREEDENCE, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 143782
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: The driver of the vehicle was driving at approximately 60 mph when he felt a drop on the backend of the vehicle. At that time, the driver lost control of the vehicle and began to fishtail and then the vehicle rolled onto its top. A witness to the incident informed the driver that he had lost his back passenger wheels off the truck in transit and this caused the loss of control. It was determined that the wheel studs had completely broken off causing this to happen. The wreck and rollover are what caused the damage to the packaging of the chemicals. The duration of the release was approximately 45 minutes. Creedence immediately contacted an emergency response hazmat clean up crew and got them to the location of the incident. They immediately began containing the spill from spreading and cleaning what had been spilt. Creedence notified the National Response Center of the spill and TCEQ was on site directing the clean up the following day.

DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: RED TOTES PRE-LINED WITH HAZMAT BAGS WERE USED TO PLACE IMPACTED BOXES INTO, WHICH STEMMED THE LEAKAGE AND REDUCED ADDITIONAL VAPOR DISPERSION. item.title: Report E-2024040289
item.description:
Report E-2024040289

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-15T15:12:24+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-12
  • City: ORANGE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 41500
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On March 12, 2024 at 1421 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Orange, Texas regarding the release of approximately (225) gallons of FERRIC SULFATE SOLUTION, Corrosive Liquid, Acidic, Inorganic, n.o.s. (UN3264, 8, III). Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors investigated and confirmed the release was caused by a load shift due to a hard brake and was contained to the trailer floor and a 100ft x 6ft area of asphalt trailing behind the unit. Contractors neutralized the release then used absorbents and the proper PPE to clean the release. Contractors were able to transfer the remaining product in the damaged tote to a new tote without complication. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (7) 55-gallon DF’s, which was then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal. **The NRC report has the city of Beaumont (which the spill took place in Orange City), this 5800 report was completed to match the NRC report for fluidity**

item.description:

  • City: SIOUX FALLS

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO-XSO contacted ERTS regarding a punctured tote as a result of improper loading. The puncture resulted in a 12-ounce release of ScaleBreak onto the wooden trailer floor and the concrete dock floor. The trailer floor was impacted in a 4’x4’ area and the dock floor was impacted in an area of 4’x4’. A Contractor performed a tote transfer and cleaned-up the release. The damaged tote was cut-up and containerized for waste disposal along with the impacted oil dry, rags, and PPE. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were impacted.

  • Description: On 03/27/2024 at approximately 1800, Dangerous Goods Adminstration received a call from Employee 5061923 at the station location in Rapid City, reporting an undeclared dangeorus goods shipment. The package consists of one fiberboard box containing one plastic jerrican. The accompanying safety data sheet identified the contents as "Quik-Foam HP" and classified the shubstance as a flammable liquid. The package was not prepared in accourdance with IATA regulations, missing the markings, labeling. packaging. and paperwork and is being held, pending an FAA investigation.

  • Description: TILX 102029 was identified as releasing the commodity from the top of the rail car during switching operations in the BNSF Railway Belen, NM Terminal on 3/27/2024. Mechanical Hazmat Responder with a local hazmat contractor responded and identified the Syphon Pipe loose and requiring approximately + turn to secure the release. The total estimated amount released was approximately 3 gallons impacting the sides of the car, protective housing and minor impacts to the track/ties/ballast.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: WE ORIGINALLY RECEIVED THIS SHIPMENT ON 10MAR ON ORIG AWB 7065-2470 AND REFUSED DUE TO NO IAC PPWK AND FUEL SMELL ADVISED THAT THEY NEED TO CLEAN. RETURNED 11MAR AND AS ACCT CHARGES DENIED DUE TO OVERLIMIT. NEW AWB 7125 5413 WAS TENDERED ON 12MAR AND AFTER ACCEPTANCE DUE TO ITEMS SHRINK WRAPPED WE WERE PHYSICAL SCREENING AND DISCOVERED 10 FUEL BOTTLES AND ENTIRE PIECE WITH STRONG FUEL SMELL. SHIPMENT WAS TENDERED AS MACHINE PTS BUT ACTUALLY WAS CAMPING GEAR AND SNOW SKIES. CTCD THE SHIPPER AND STATED THAT THEY NEED TO TRANSPORTED BY GROUND.

item.title: Report E-2024040206
item.description:
Report E-2024040206

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-11T15:11:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-08
  • City: LORDSTOWN
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 9500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XAY experienced a UN2922 Nalcon 7634 release from 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 100-gallons of product released to 60' x 20' area of the concrete dock and a 40' x 15' area of the asphalt parking lot due to a forklift puncture. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Absorbents were then deployed and worked into the impacted area to clean the release. All impacted absorbents were containerized into (8) 55-gallon poly drums. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with impacted absorbents and PPE into a cubic yard box. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On April 4, 2024 at 1610 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in San Antonio, Texas regarding (10) 330-gallon IBC plastic totes containing DCA-19002 (Environmentally hazardous substances, liquid, n.o.s) UN3082, 9, III, that was involved in a vehicular crash. Contractors arrived to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Contractors were able to collect the material from the totes using a vac truck and proper PPE. Contractors collected 1800 gallons of waste that was taken offsite for proper disposal.

  • Description: XPO-XTM contacted ERTS regarding a punctured leaking 5-gallon PAIL containing Endurastrip. The PAIL was punctured by a Forklift. The PAIL released all 5-gallons that impacted the wooden trailer floor and the concrete dock floor. The trailer floor had an impact area of 28’x5’. The dock floor had an impact area of 10’x1’. A Contractor cleaned up the release and repalletized the remaining, un-damaged product. Two drums of waste were generated for disposal. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were impacted by this incident.

  • Description: On April 2, 2024, one (1) 1-gallon pail of paint was crushed in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the top of the pail. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted site. Terminal personnel deployed absorbents to the release, swept them in with hand tools and containerized all spent absorbents in one (1) 30-gallon drum. LSH personnel overpacked the one (1) damaged pail in the same 30-gallon drum. All waste was staged onsite for future disposal.

  • Description: Captain notified to SOC in NRT at 11:42L by ACARS. Thermal containment bag was used for 8A customer's IPAD, which was stuck on rail of her seat and broken. Upon arrival at NRT, CS SPVR retrieved the bag and IPAD was crushed. The customer agreed for us to confiscate at NRT due to no way to repair. We learned that she was not aware of dropping her IPAD at her seat rail, when she was reclining her seat, then she heard the sound of a crack which caused by breaking IPAD. No fire, no smoke and no heat were produced, but for safety, FA used the thermal containment bag and placed at designated location during flight. Passenger Information:, Name: Carol Pulliam Address: 167 N. Cleveland Ave#400 Oceanside, CA 92054 Phone: 951-543-8608 Email: myrtle007@sbcglobal.net

item.title: Report I-2024040037
item.description:
Report I-2024040037

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-11T15:11:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-14
  • City: MIDDLETOWN
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: UNLOAD SUPERVISOR CALLED THE LEAKING PACKAGE IN QUESTION OUT ON THE RESPONDER CHANNEL RESPONDER PROPERLY CONTAINED AND CLEANED UP THE SPILLED AREA BEFORE TRANSPORTING PACKAGE BACK TO THE DMP ONCE AT THE DMR THE PACKAGE HAD NO OUTSIDE MARKINGS OR INDICATORS OF IT BEING A HAZARDOUS MATERIAL SO THE RESPONDER BEGAN PROCESS THE LEAKING PACKAGE. THE PACKAGE WAS NOT IN THE SYSTEM SO IT NEEDED TO BE GREEN BAGGED, DURING THE SOLIDIFICATION PROCESS, THE STRONG ODOR BECAME APPARENT. WHEN ASKED FOR INGREDIENTS, WE FOUND THE SDS OF THE PRODUCT(MARYKATE ON AND OFF HULL& BOTTOM CLEANER) IN QUESTION AND TURNED OUT TO BE A CLASS 8 CORROSIVE. WE IMMDIATELY STOPPED PROCESSING AND CALLED THE HAZMAT SUPPORT CENTER TO REPORT THE PACKAGE. PART VII- RECOMMENDATIONS/ACTIONS TAKEN TO PREVENT RECURRENCE

item.title: Report I-2024040043
item.description:
Report I-2024040043

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-11T15:11:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-13
  • City: LONDON
  • State: RI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED AIRLINES HOLDINGS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: From employee witness: During a cabin walk-through, I noticed a strong chemical smell. I could see a flight attendant speaking with a passenger in the aisle of the B zone cabin. They were standing next to a Polaris seat with a flashlight. I immediately asked the flight attendant what was happening, and where the smell was coming from. He showed me a broken cell phone belonging to 12A Norris Dodson. From what I was told, Mr. Dodson woke sometime prior and realized his phone was no longer on his person. He notified flight attendant and asked for help in retrieving it. In the process of searching for the phone, flight attendant activated the electronic seat controls. The phone was crushed by the mechanism and the lithium battery was punctured. When I arrived at the seat, the phone was hot to the touch. There was no smoke, or any other indicator of fire. But to be safe, between the chemical smell and the heat of the phone, I decided to place the phone in the thermal containment bag. The pilots were notified, and the information was sent to Ground staff.

item.title: Report I-2024040050
item.description:
Report I-2024040050

Identified by scraper @ 2024-04-11T15:11:27+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-03-07
  • City: Bridgeport
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: MARTIN TRANSPORT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 20712
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Driver was traveling north bound on I-75 north of Flint, MI when he was pulled over by Michigan State Police at 16:15 ET for a lane restriction violation. Upon inspection of the tractor/trailer, the trooper detected a leak coming out from under the ss skin on the bottom of the trailer just in front of the rollover protection. A tub was placed underneath the leak to contain it until the cleanup crew from Michigan Spill Response arrived on scene. After a short period of time, the leak stopped and there was only residue on the trailer. At that time, the top of the trailer was visually inspected and right above the area of the leak, there was a 3" washout cap that had fresh residue in the area which indicated that it had leaked. When Michigan Spill Response arrived on scene, they went to the top of the trailer and determined that the front washout cap was loose. They removed the washout cap, inspected the gasket, and then secured the washout cap to the threaded connection. After replacing the cap, a surge test was conducted on site and the trailer showed no signs of of any further leakage. Michigan Spill Response cleaned the residue from the trailer and disposed of the product that was collected in the catch pan placed underneath the trailer. Once the residue was removed rom the trailer, the load continued on without further incident. L

  • Description: XPO-XMI contacted ERTS regarding a punctured supersac containing 100Y Litharge Lead Monoxide. The supersac was punctured by a forklift resulting in the release of approximately 1lb of product onto the wooden trailer floor in a 2’x2’ area. A Contractor responded at a scheduled time to perform a supersac transfer and clean-up the released product. A CUYD and a 55-gallon DF was generated for waste disposal. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were affected by this incident.

  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 7500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO-XTM contacted ERTS regarding a punctured leaking tote containing Predator MR2516. The tote was punctured by a forklift and released approximately 35-gallons of product onto the wooden trailer floor and concrete underneath the trailer. The trailer floor impact area was 18'x18' and the impact area underneath the trailer was 8'x20'. A Contractor performed a tote transfer, cut-up pallets that were impacted by the release, and cleaned-up the release on the trailer floor. Five drums of waste were generated for disposal. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were affected by this incident.

  • Description: XPO-XNJ contacted ERTS regarding (6) damaged 1-gallon jugs of Heavy Duty Foam Degreaser that fell during transit as a result of improper loading / improper blocking and bracing. Approximately 2-gallons of product released onto the concrete dock floor. A Contractor overpacked the damaged product and neutralized the impacted boxes, plastic, cardboard, and trash can liners using Citri Acid. Three drums of waste were generated for disposal. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were affected by this incident.

  • Description: On April 2, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of resin solution was punctured by the shipper's skid and released approximately two (2) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel utilized hand tools, cleaners, absorbents, and a sprayer unit to remediate the site. All spent absorbents and debris were collected and containerized into two (2) 35-gallon drums. The damaged 55-gallon drum of product was placed into one (1) 85-gallon drum. All containers were staged onsite for future disposal.

The waste was transported back to the XPO terminal in Phoenix, AZ for terminal personnel to manage.

  • City: PHILADELPHIA

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A pallet of Aldahol was shipped on a local service truck to Veolia's ten day intransit facility in Philadelphia, PA. Upon opening the service truck to offload the materials, the facility crew noted a pallet of items that had broken apart during transportation. Cardboard boxes were no longer secured to the pallet with some on their sides with obvious signs of leakage from the inner packages. An investigation revealed the stretch-wrap securing the boxes to the pallet failed during transportation due to heavy containers stacked on top of lighter weight containers. The pallet was not sufficiently wrapped to secure the boxes for transportation. Trained Veolia facility employees removed the stretch wrap and upright the packages. The leaking packages were overpacked and the material was repalletized appropriately. The stretch wrap was wrapped to the pallet of containers utilizing a mechanical means to ensure proper stretch wrap tension and securement to the pallet.

  • Description: On 03/20/2024, during cruise phase of flight DL182 (JFK-FCO), a passenger identified a vape pen in a lavatory trash bin that was smoking. The flight attendant retrieved the vape pen from the trash bin and noted that the device was still smoking/"hissing". The flight attendant met with the captain, and they elected to remove the battery and place the vape pen into a containment bag. The captain then returned to the flight deck and contacted dispatch. A decision was made to continue to FCO as the vape pen had stopped smoking. No Flight Attendant or customer injuries were reported. The NRC and FAA were notified.

ERTS reviewed the SDS with terminal personnel who felt comfortable cleaning the release with the proper available PPE on-site. the waste was placed into a 5-gallon metal drum. The super sack was placed into a yard box to continue transit.
